name: Kepler-342
scenarioDescription:
The Kepler-342 Exoplanetary System

Kepler-342 is a star with 1.9099999999999993 times the mass of the Sun, and 1.47 times its radius. It is located 2607.91 light years away from the solar system.

Kepler-342 is known to have 4 exoplanets in orbit around it.

Kepler-342 b

Kepler-342 b was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.13 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 15.17 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-342.

The mass of Kepler-342 b is 6.76 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-342 b is 2.25 that of Earth. At 6.76 Earth masses, Kepler-342 b is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-342 c

Kepler-342 c was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.18 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 26.23 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-342.

The mass of Kepler-342 c is 4.85 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-342 c is 1.96 that of Earth. At 4.85 Earth masses, Kepler-342 c is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.

Kepler-342 d

Kepler-342 d was discovered by the Kepler observatory using the transit method. Its discovery was announced in 2014-03. Its semi-major axis is 0.24 astronomical units, as compared to Earth's which is 1 astronomical unit. It takes 39.46 Earth days to complete an orbit around its host star, Kepler-342.

The mass of Kepler-342 d is 8.58 times the mass of Earth. The radius of Kepler-342 d is 2.49 that of Earth. At 8.58 Earth masses, Kepler-342 d is a so called Super Earth. Super Earths could be terrestrial worlds like Earth, but they could also be ocean worlds or terrestrial worlds wrapped in a substantial atmosphere, in which case some refer to them as Mini Neptunes. No Super Earths are known to exist in our solar system, but if it exists, the so-called Planet Nine could very well be a super Earth, as it is hypothesized to have a mass between five and ten Earth masses.
description: 3D visualisation and gravity simulation of the exoplanet system Kepler-342, which contains 4 planets and was discovered by Kepler.
